content: Eligibility for health benefits under CHIP is available to different groups through various federal authorities and mechanisms. This includes children, pregnant women, parents, and childless adults who may be covered under the CHIP state plan or special waiver authority. Title XXI defines a targeted low-income child as someone under age 19 without health insurance and not eligible for Medicaid under pre-CHIP rules. States can set the income level for targeted low-income children up to 200% of the federal poverty level. States have the flexibility to expand eligibility for all children under 19 years of age. CHIPRA reduces federal payments for higher-income CHIP children, using the regular Medicaid matching rate for those with family incomes exceeding 300% of poverty. Federal CHIP payments for higher-income CHIP children will use the regular Medicaid matching rate for those with family incomes over 300% of poverty. States can cover these children under Medicaid or create a separate CHIP program. Medicaid rules apply for Medicaid coverage, while Title XXI rules apply for separate CHIP programs. Federal CHIP funds cover the program costs, and states may cover targeted low-income children through Medicaid expansion or separate CHIP programs. Prior to CHIPRA, states had various ways to cover adult pregnant women, including through Section 1115 waivers or CHIP state plan amendments. As of October 2007, 17 states offered pregnancy-related services to adults using CHIP funds, with 6 states using waivers and 12 states extending coverage through state plan amendments. In FY2008, 12 states extended coverage to unborn children of adult pregnant women through CHIP state plan amendments, with most states also covering undocumented aliens. CHIPRA introduced a new option for states to cover pregnant women under CHIP, with specific eligibility conditions to meet. Pregnant women can be temporarily enrolled in CHIP for up to two months before formal eligibility determination. Benefits include prenatal, delivery, and postpartum care, with infants eligible for Medicaid or CHIP up to age one. States may continue coverage through waivers and offer postpartum services. Legal immigrants arriving after August 22, 1996, are also eligible. CHIPRA clarified that states can offer postpartum services to pregnant women and children who are lawfully residing in the United States and are otherwise eligible for Medicaid or CHIP coverage, waiving the five-year bar for legal immigrants. The law requires sponsors' income and resources to be considered for eligibility, ensuring they are financially responsible for the individual. CHIPRA allowed states to waive the five-year bar for Medicaid or CHIP coverage for pregnant women and children lawfully residing in the U.S. The provision ensures that sponsors are financially responsible for the individual, and states must redetermine eligibility annually for those whose legal residence documentation expires. States must meet coverage benchmarks to receive enhanced FMAP for parents in FY2013. Benchmark-equivalent coverage under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP) must include basic benefits like hospital services, physician services, and well-child care, as well as 75% of the actuarial value for additional services like prescription drugs and vision/hearing services. CHIPRA brought changes to mental health and substance abuse coverage under CHIP, ensuring financial requirements are consistent for medical/surgical and mental health/substance abuse benefits. The new law under CHIP ensures that financial requirements and treatment limitations for mental health and substance abuse benefits must be no more restrictive than those for medical and surgical benefits. It also streamlines coordination between public and private coverage, including making loss of Medicaid/CHIP eligibility a "qualifying event" for purchasing employer-sponsored coverage. CHIPRA 2009 aimed to enhance data collection and reporting for CHIP and Medicaid, directing the development of child health quality measures and standardized reporting formats. The new law CHIPRA 2009 directs the Secretary of HHS to develop child health quality measures and reporting formats for CHIP and Medicaid. It adds reporting requirements to states' annual CHIP reports, including data on eligibility criteria and access to care. A study on children's access to care under Medicaid and CHIP will be conducted by GAO. Reports to Congress under CHIPRA 2009 detail findings and recommendations for improving access and quality of care for children under Medicaid and CHIP. A new federal evaluation will assess 10 states with approved CHIP plans, examining outreach strategies, cost-sharing effects, disenrollment factors, and retention issues. Federal financing of CHIP includes appropriations for states' annual allotments, reallocation of funds, and factors like matching rates and administrative expense caps. The BBA 97 allocated approximately $40 billion for CHIP allotments from FY1998 to FY2007, with varying funding levels each year. The funding dropped to under $3.2 billion in FY2002-FY2004, known as the "CHIP dip," due to budget constraints. The 110th Congress attempted to reauthorize CHIP with bills like H.R. 976 and H.R. 3963, but they were vetoed by President George W. Bush. The allotment of the annual federal CHIP appropriation among the states is determined by a formula set in law. The annual federal CHIP appropriation is determined by a formula set in law. Prior to CHIPRA, the national appropriation was divided among states based on survey estimates of low-income uninsured children. CHIP allotments are separate funding accounts for each state and territory, calculated to not exceed the national appropriation. The CHIP allotments for states and territories are separate funding accounts that do not exceed the national appropriation. These allotments are available for a certain period of time, with FY2009 allotments only available for two years. States can draw from the earliest active account until fully expended, then move to the next available allotment. The FY2009 federal CHIP allotments for states are determined by a formula based on growth factors and projections submitted to the Secretary of HHS. The FY2009 CHIP allotments for states and territories are determined by a formula based on growth factors and projections submitted to the Secretary of HHS. The largest of these amounts will be increased by 10% to serve as the state's federal CHIP allotment, with reductions if the national appropriation is insufficient. FY2010 allotments will be calculated based on various factors, including unspent funds from previous years and Contingency Fund payments. FY2011 and FY2013 allotments will be "rebased" on prior year spending, while FY2012 allotments will be based on the FY2011 allotment. For FY2012, state CHIP allotments will be "rebased" on prior year spending by multiplying the state's growth factor with the previous year's federal CHIP spending. Unspent allotments are redistributed to other states at the end of the period, with rules varying by fiscal year. Additionally, up to half of unspent FY2005 allotments could be redistributed to further delay shortfalls. The Child Enrollment Contingency Fund created under CHIPRA prevents federal funding shortfalls for states. It provides direct payments to shortfall states for CHIP children above a target enrollment level, capped at 20% of the national allotment amount. CHIP is a federal-state matching program similar to Medicaid, with the state's share determined by the federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP). The CHIP program is a federal-state matching program where the federal government matches state spending from CHIP accounts. The state's share of program spending for Medicaid is determined by the federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP). The enhanced FMAP (E-FMAP) for CHIP reduces a state's share of expenditures by 30% compared to the regular FMAP. The E-FMAP ranges from 65% to 83.09% for CHIP, with a ceiling of 85% and a floor of 65%. Federal spending for CHIP administrative expenses is capped at 10%. Under CHIPRA, federal CHIP bonus payments are available to states that increase Medicaid child enrollment and implement specific outreach and enrollment activities. The funding for these payments comes from an initial $3.225 billion appropriation in FY2009 and unspent national allotment and redistribution amounts.
